summary: This document is a chain of email correspondence from November 2021 between legal teams involved in United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell. The emails primarily concern scheduling a call to discuss identifying a trial witness from JPMorgan Chase and the provision of a subpoena to the bank.

persons.name: Allison Stoddart
persons.context: Attorney from WilmerHale corresponding with the prosecution to schedule a call and discuss obtaining a trial appearance subpoena for a JPMorgan witness.

persons.name: Anjan Sahni
persons.context: Prosecutor with the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York copied on emails regarding witness identification and scheduling.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case referenced in the email subject line, United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell, 20 Cr. 330 (AJN).

connections.description: Corresponding as legal professionals on opposite sides (defense/prosecution) of the Ghislaine Maxwell case to coordinate on witness matters.
Stoddart is an attorney from WilmerHale, corresponding on matters related to Maxwell's criminal trial.

events.title: Jury Selection for Maxwell Trial
events.description: Jury selection is mentioned as being scheduled and underway, making scheduling difficult for the legal teams.

events.title: Discussion on JPMorgan Trial Witness
events.description: The prosecution and defense correspond about identifying an appropriate witness from JPMorgan Chase for the trial and providing a subpoena.

keyFacts: The emails show coordination between the defense (WilmerHale) and prosecution (SDNY) regarding trial logistics for United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell in late 2021.
A key topic is identifying and subpoenaing a witness from JPMorgan Chase to appear at the trial, indicating the bank's potential relevance to the case.
Jury selection was actively underway in November 2021, creating scheduling challenges for the legal teams.

The correspondence involves redacted recipients, indicated by blank 'To:' fields and references to 'he' being available, suggesting other involved parties whose names are not disclosed in this excerpt.
